Edit: So this Tuesday is obviously December 2nd and not the November date that was here earlier.  That's what I get for trying to cut, paste, and edit when I'm sleep deprived.

Here's the corrected version

I've been doing a lot more teaching than performing lately.  In addition to this series, over the last year I've gotten to teach CircleSinging and Vocal Improvisation workshops in Boston, the Catskills, Maine, West Virginia and Washington State (where I'll be again next month, this time teaching an advanced class for a group of jazz singers in Seattle).  I'm also being asked by choruses to lead CircleSinging workshops for them.  The first of those will be happening in January.  I've also been putting together a (still to be named) Vocal Improv performance group with some incredible singers.

I do have a couple of NY/NJ area performances coming up:
 
1) A house concert in a beautiful Soho loft at 1pm on Sunday, Dec. 21st.
I'll be one of the solo performers and this will also be the debut of the aforementioned Vocal Improv group.  If you're interested, you'll probably have to RSVP for at this one, so get in touch with me for details if you'd like to come.

2) I'll also be one of the performers at Wicked Faire IV: The Chocolate Factory in Whippany, NJ.  Feb. 20th - 22nd.  I'll probably be doing mostly vocal looping with some singer/songwriter stuff mixed in.

But first, this coming Tuesday will be the final evening of CircleSinging in the First Tuesday series that I've been running this Fall.  It's been a such a pleasure to do and we've made amazing, beautiful music together.  I hope to be able to get another series going soon but for the moment, this is it.  This is a completely open event. Anyone who doesn't want to participate as one of the singers can be audience.  Either way, it's a powerful experience (and some may just change their mind and join us in creating these pieces of improvised music).  
Details, a description of CircleSinging and a short bio for me <lj-cut text="are behind the cut">: 

Date:	
Tuesday, December 2nd, 2008
Time:	
7:00pm - 9:00pm
Location:	
Old Stone House
Street:	
336 3rd St. at 5th Ave
City/Town:	
Brooklyn, NY

There's a tiny little park on the block between 3rd and 4th Streets at 5th Ave. and you'll see the Old Stone House in the middle of it.

Circlesinging, as practiced by Bobby McFerrin and Voicestra, is a vocal improvisation technique in which a circle of singers takes melodic and rhythmic cues (parts) from a skilled leader, together creating songs unique to the moment. As the leader cues out old parts and introduces new ones, the song continues and changes without stopping, at times supporting individual solos, always grounded in attentive listening.

Ben has been teaching various forms of Vocal Improvisation and Group Singing for over two decades.  In 2005, he took a five-day master class in Circlesinging with Bobby McFerrin.  His other teachers of Circlesinging, Vocal Percussion and Vocal Improv have included David Worm and Rhiannon (including her master classes for Teachers of Vocal Improvisation) .  Ben has been a member of the Vocal Improv performance groups "Vox Pop" and "The Tritones".  His songs have been published in Carry It On, Sing Out Magazine, The Washington Post, and the book "Hearing Everyone's Voice".

Here are directions to get to there, courtesy of http://www.theoldstonehouse.org :

By Subway
Take the F or the R to Fourth Avenue, or the R to Union Street.

By Bus
Take the B63 Bus to Third Street and Fifth Avenue

By Car
The Old Stone House is located between Fourth and Fifth Avenues and Third and Fourth Streets in the Park Slope neighborhood of Brooklyn. On street parking is available.

(Note that if you do take the F or R train to either the 4th Ave station (which is at 9th St.) or the Union St. station (which is also on 4th Ave) that you'll have to walk east (uphill) to 5th Ave. and that 4th St. doesn't go through between 4th and 5th Aves.)

How is it that SNL, after many years of being really bad and unfunny (at least on the rare occasions that I would bother to check it out) to being ridiculously funny again?  A and I must have watched this segment at least 3 times, laughing hysterically.

I'm talking about the bit they did about the AIG bailout(s) during the Weekend Update Thursday edition from October 9th.  The news facts were all real and accurate (at least as I understand them).  What's so hysterical is their reactions to those facts.  They reflected my own (and I'm sure, so many other people's) reactions, so brilliantly, that it was quite cathartic.    

The bit in question is 14 mins and 19 seconds in, which is a little over half way through the middle section.  When you click the link it'll say "Select an episode below".  Ignore that.  It'll then play a commercial, after which it will start playing the show.  The debate sketch at the beginning is funny enough, but old news already.  If you want to skip the earlier parts of the show, click just past the middle of the middle segment (they'll play another commercial before starting that segment, unfortunately, but at least it's short.)  Let me know what you think.  (I know; a lot of you probably saw this a month and a half ago, already.  So I'm lagging.)  I suspect that even (or perhaps, especially) the libertarians among you will be on the same page with me on this. 


http://www.nbc.com/Saturday_Night_Live/video/episodes/?vid=742181#vid=742181

Says McCain "Bomb Bomb Bomb Iran!"

No RSVP is required, but I'd love to hear from you if you think you might be there so that I can get an idea of how many people to expect.

Circlesinging, as practiced by Bobby McFerrin and Voicestra, is a vocal improvisation technique in which a circle of singers takes melodic and rhythmic cues (parts) from a skilled leader, together creating songs unique to the moment. As the leader cues out old parts and introduces new ones, the song continues and changes without stopping, at times supporting individual solos, always grounded in attentive listening.  Participants are welcome at any level of singing experience.

While I'm here on LJ, it occurs to me that I should probably post something about a really cool vocal improv gig that I'm part of tonight at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe on the off chance that any of you might be able to make it at the very last minute.  Here's what my friend, Kate Richards (who I'm sitting in with along with several stellar singers), wrote up about it:

Kate Richards with Frank Wagner and Friends
Tuesday, August 19, 2008
8 PM - two sets
Nuyorican Poets Cafe
236 E. 3rd St. between Aves. B & C, New York
$10 cover, no minimum

The "Women Take the Bandstand" series at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe presents singer/songwriter Kate Richards with Frank Wagner on bass, and special guests, on August 19th, at 8 pm.

Kate Richards worked the New England coffee house circuit in the 90's as a solo folk artist and in a captivating duo with guitarist Jonathan Carroll (currently living in Oregon). She also collaborated with Barbara Shepard and Kriss Santala in a vocal trio in New Haven, playing Toad's Place and street festivals. After a 10-year stint as a music therapist, she returns to the stage with veteran bassist Frank Wagner of Primary Colours, www.modalmoods.com, for clear and powerful renditions of some familiar standards and a few surprises. Her originals lean toward the folk/country genre and that's where her voice soars.

For the second set, Kate will invite special guests [including Andrea Wolper, Alexis Parsons, Ben Silver, Kendra Shank, Laurie Newell, Nik Munson, Steve Sandberg, Tia Hanna] to join her for a dynamic and extraordinary improvised vocal performance. Using some of the structures they've learned from Rhiannon and Bobby McFerrin, this group will create musical compositions in the moment - 100% improvised.

If you know anyone who could use work today and/or tomorrow in Brooklyn and/or next week in Boston, please forward the message below to them -- it would help out my friend , who is staying with us while she does the NY part of this job and had the person that she had hired fall through. I did a couple of shifts with her yesterday and had a good time. She's fun to hang out with.



From:
Subject: HELP WANTED this week in Brooklyn, NY


Hello! I'm visiting Brooklyn on a fun summer job, and I need help with it.

Please help me hand out prizes this week, ASAP, August 19th-20th in
Brooklyn. Fun for an outgoing person who tends to smile and likes to
talk to strangers. Technically, it's marketing, but it's fun
marketing that makes people want to talk to us. Each "event" is two
hours long and up to 3 events can be done in one day. The work pays
$20 per 2-hour event.

I was scheduled to do this work early this week but
my teammate is not available and I need to find replacement(s). Ideally I need people who will commit to working 2-3
shifts on the same day, but anything is better than nothing. All
work is done between 7am-7pm (store hours).

The job includes identifying winners, giving away sweepstakes prizes
and asking short voluntary surveys of the winners and a few
non-winners. Some of the "events" will be quiet/slow and some are
busy/exciting (it's unpredictable). Some of the time the job is just
sitting/standing around chatting and hanging out with each other
and/or with the store staff, who are friendly and often offer
complimentary bottled water, soft drinks and coffee. The tasks that
we do are not complicated and if you are able to talk with people and
write legibly, you're qualified. Since we are handing out prizes,
you MUST be over 18 to do the job.

Work is outside and mostly in the shade, requires standing on your
feet for most of the day. (Rest for 15-45 minutes between the
"events," at our option. if you want to crank through the day and
take shorter breaks, we can do that.)

There is a uniform. I will provide a uniform T-shirt, and I have a
few sizes of men's or women's khaki pants, but it's easier if you
already have your own khaki bottoms. Shorts, pants, skirts, and
cargo-style are all fine. Wear comfortable, plain, solid-color
black, brown or white closed-toe shoes. (Sorry, no pink flip flops
with purple ribbons!)

I have a car and will drive us between locations. In some parts of
Brooklyn I can even pick you up and drop you off at your doorstep. I
have a cooler in my car that can be shared, and I have lots of snacks
(from healthy/raw to salty/sugary/junk), which you are welcome to
enjoy while you work with

me.

Please comment at if you would be available to
work, and include what day
or days you might be available. If you know someone with a flexible
schedule or who needs very short-term or IMMEDIATE employment/income,
this might be just the thing to forward on to them. Your help is appreciated.

THANKS!

I think this is the first time I've been on LJ in close to three months.  It's been a very busy time.  On any number of occasions, I've thought to log in for a few minutes to check my friends list and then the idea seemed daunting - where would I start.  I decided to wait until I had a bit more time (ha).

From an AP article of about an hour ago titled "Cheney, others OK'd harsh interrogations":

The officials also took care to insulate President Bush from a series of meetings where CIA interrogation methods, including waterboarding, which simulates drowning, were discussed and ultimately approved.



From Antony and Cleopatra Act II, Scene 7 (in which Menas and Pompey were discussing Marc Antony, Octavius Ceasar, and Lepidus, with whom Pompey had just make a treaty):

MENAS.
These three world-sharers, these competitors,
Are in thy vessel: let me cut the cable;
And when we are put off, fall to their throats:
All then is thine.

POMPEY.
Ah, this thou shouldst have done,
And not have spoke on't! In me 'tis villainy:
In thee't had been good service. Thou must know
'Tis not my profit that does lead mine honour:
Mine honour it. Repent that e'er thy tongue
Hath so betray'd thine act: being done unknown,
I should have found it afterwards well done;
But must condemn it now. Desist, and drink.

Any suggestions?

In my last post, on August 4th, I made the following comment: "If I had a paid membership, I'd consider taking a poll (assuming I could figure out how)."  Later that morning, Live Journal sent me an email to let me know that I had received an anonymous gift of 12 months of paid account time.  I am appreciative, curious, and a little embarrassed.  When I made the comment it really wasn't meant as a request or gift suggestion and it didn't occur to me that someone might buy me a paid account.  That said, it's a lovely gift and I'll try to learn the various ways to make good use of it.

I also wish that I had managed to post this thank you much sooner than this and I am concerned that it might not be seen by the generous person that gave me the gift.  If that's you and you really don't want to give away your identity, please respond anonymously to let me know that you saw this.  On the other hand if you wish to reveal your identity, well as I said, I am curious.  Either way, I feel warm and happy that one of you was moved to do that.  Thanks again.

Last X-mas season, my friend, <lj user="tactisle"> , wrote:
"Know what I want for my present? I want a weekend without any of my friends or extended family getting broken, getting hurt, getting their stuff smashed, getting sick, getting robbed, getting sacked, getting stranded, getting dumped, getting bereaved, getting depressed, getting migraines, getting hung over, or getting up in the middle of the night just to worry some more about all of the above."

Man, did I relate to that!  I did then and I do now.  Way too many (although any at all would, of course, be "way too many") people that I love are in crisis right now, including medical, legal, financial, and intense grieving over tragic loss.  I'm way too tired to articulate this any better than...  It sucks!

I think that part of the reason that I was as disturbed as I was (not that I need a reason) by the "Rope. Tree. Journalist. Some Assembly Required." tee shirt that I saw on line last night, was that I was still sitting with some of the emotional impact of the intro at www.abolishthenword.com which I had viewed earlier in the day.

So I googled information about a very recent executive order from Bush and found a pretty useful article and even the order itself on WorldNetDaily which had a fair amount of advertising with a very conservative slant.  One of those ads was for a tee shirt company ( thoseshirts.com ) with the slogans "Right shirts done right".  I was curious and followed the link.

The shirt that I found most disturbing said in large bold letters: "Rope. Tree. Journalist. Some Assembly Required."

Other shirts included one that featured the following Ann Coulter quote "We should invade their countries, kill their leaders, and convert them to Christianity.", a happy face with the words "Imagine no liberals", "celebrate diversity" with the image of an number of different kinds of handguns, and one that said "Alcohol Tobacco & Firearms should be a convenience store, not a government agency".

By JOHN HOLUSHA
Published: April 28, 2006

President Bush said today that he thought the national anthem should be sung in English, not the Spanish language version released by a recording company recently.

The song, recorded by a chorus of Latin pop stars, is being distributed to Spanish-language radio stations to be played Monday morning to coincide with immigrant rights demonstrations that are scheduled in many cities across the nation.

Speaking to reporters in the White House Rose Garden, Mr. Bush made it clear that he considered the language difference as part of the immigration issue.

After saying he did not consider the anthem sung in Spanish to have the same value as the anthem sung in English, Mr. Bush said: "I think people who want to be a citizen of this country ought to learn English. And they ought to learn to sing the anthem in English."

Mr. Bush was responding to a question following the release today of the Spanish-language version of the song called "Nuestro Himno" or "Our Anthem."

Adam Kidron, the British music producer who released the song, responded to Mr. Bush's comments by saying that it was not intended "to discourage immigrants from learning English and embracing American culture," according to The Associated Press. "We instead view `Nuestro Himno' as a song that affords those immigrants that have not yet learned the English language the opportunity to fully understand the character of "The Star-Spangled Banner," the American flag and the ideals of freedom that they represent. Mr. Bush also addressed one of the goals of Monday's demonstrations: a show of force by immigrants who hope to demonstrate their economic power by staying home from work and boycotting stores.

"I am not a supporter of boycotts," Mr. Bush said. "I am a supporter of comprehensive immigration reform."

Congress is currently wrangling over the question of how to deal with people who, though not legal residents of the country, provide vital labor in agriculture, construction and service industries.

The House of Representatives has passed a bill that would strengthen border security and make being in the country illegally a felony. The Senate has considered, but not yet adopted a milder approach, that would provide a path to citizenship for those who have been in the country the longest. Mr. Bush has said he prefers the Senate version.

I'm out of town and just got a last minute call seeking a video camera to document Brenda Howard's memorial at noon today at the GLBT Community Center on W 13th St. in Manhattan.  As I understand it, the memorial was going to be documented by an organization that I won't name the produces public access tv shows.  Unfortunately, it sounds as if they never called to confirm that they'll be there.

For decades, Brenda was always putting her time and energy into many important causes because she saw the need.  From GLBT activism (among many other things, she was one of the organizers of the first marches to commemorate the anniversary of Stonewall) to the anti-war movement, Brenda was there... working, educating, and soliciting support.  She cared deeply about freedom, fairness, and people and she was willing to fight passionately for what she cared about.

I'm sad that I won't be there today, that I didn't make it to her funeral, and much sadder that I didn't get to the hospital to visit with her when she was dying.

It would be a shame if this commemoration of her life didn't get documented on video.  I have a phone number to call up until the last minute if someone is available with a camera.  I'll check back here in a while to see if anyone can help but if you are able to and have my cell phone number, please give me a call.

Thanks.

This past Thursday at about 9am I was going up some steps and tripped.  My right hand got jammed into one of the steps and I fractured the top section of my middle finger.  It's a minor fracture, I believe, but what was more significant was that I broke the nail-bed.  (The nail was broken going across the middle - kinda jagged like - and had cut the flesh underneath.  It wasn't pretty.

I had surgery that evening in which the nail was removed and the area underneath was stitched.  Then (part of?) the nail was stitched back on, I think.  The anesthetic was local and once the surgeon became convinced that I really was feeling what he was doing he gave me a fourth shot.  Right into the bone this time - Big Ow!  After that, I felt tugging, the vibrations of the stitches going through, and unpleasant numbness, but not the acute pain of having my fingernail removed, etc.

Oh yeah, the ironic part... The steps I was climbing were the ones in front of the Red Cross building.  I was on my way to take a First Aid and CPR class.

and neither do many of my friends and lovers.  On the front page of the Science Times section of today's New York Times the main article (written by one Benedict Carey) has the headline "Straight, Gay or Lying?  Bisexuality Revisited.  Gee, it's been a little while now since some big institution in either the mainstream or queer world has loudly denied my existence - it's been kinda nice.

It seems some psychologists in Toronto and Chicago have done a study using 101 "young adult men" in which "the men watched a series of erotic movies, some involving only women, others involving only men.

"Using a sensor to monitor sexual arousal, the researchers found what the expected: gay men showed arousal to images of men and little arousal to images of women, and heterosexual men showed arousal to women but not to men.

"But the men in the study who described themselves as bisexual did not have patterns of arousal that were consistent with their stated attraction to men and to women.  Instead, about three-quarters of the group had arousal patterns identical to gay men; the rest were indistinguishable from heterosexuals."

Well I don't know what kind of "sensor" they were using, but I have some built in sensor equipment that has shown me different results!

The article says that the study is scheduled to be published in the journal of Psychological Science.

FRIDAY, JANUARY 28th at 7:30pm
Many Voices Concert (Featuring Pete Seeger) 

OK, I'm excited!  Six (6!) choruses will be performing (at the same time) a song that I co-wrote and co-arranged as the big finale of this program.  (I've written only one other choral song and the chorus that I wrote it for disbanded before ever performing it.)

I am also singing as part of a trio and then soloing during the first piece of the night, Peace Salaam Shalom as sung by a "pick-up" chorus of Peoples' Music Network members.  The trio will be introducing that song with a very short rendition of the song Circle 'Round for Freedom.

During the evening, six different choral groups will be doing 3 songs each, Pete Seeger will be performing, and at the end all the groups will come together to sing the finale (see the first paragraph).

Since I also have a gig in which I'm one of two acts next Sat (which I will post something about very very soon), I'm hoping that this big concert tomorrow will help me to draw a substantially bigger audience.  (I may put flyers on all the seats in the auditorium.)  

For anyone in the area who may feel like coming to this concert tonight that I've just been bragging about, it will be at 
Brooklyn High School for the Arts
345 Dean Street, between 3rd and 4th Avenues
Brooklyn, NY
Tickets $20

As big a deal as this is for me, though, it is much more important for me to bring people in for the gig next week since it will be, after all, _my_ gig as opposed to being one in which I am participating.  I promise, details will follow.

I am very much wanting, and intend to try, to use LJ more actively (both posting and reading.  I expect this to be challenging primarily because of time issues.  There has been so much going on in my life, personally and (at least lately) professionally, very good and truly horrible that has kept me from taking the time to be here.  It is also partially because of all of that that I am wanting to so much.

My intentions:  For the very short term (like the next 10 days), I plan to use LJ primarily to let friends (and anyone else who choses to read what I write) know about what's going on professionally and plug upcoming stuff).  After that, I'm hoping (and I invite you to push me on this) also share about what has been going on for me and also my family on a personal level over the last couple of years.  

I'm feeling such a strong need to do that in the face of some of the isolation patterns that i've been running (I know it may not look that way from the outside, but it's pretty intense) and it is very challenging for me to do so.  And NOT JUST because of time.

After paying for domain names for a couple of years, I finally got a rudimentary website up earlier this month.  Much will be added as time goes by but I'm excited by what's there so far and would love to know what you all think.  (I've already gotten what I think is some really good advise from yesthattom which I haven't had a chance to implement yet.)

It's at www.bensilvermusic.com

From a speech that Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. delivered at the 11th Convention of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference in Atlanta, GA on August 16, 1967:

"And I say to you today, that if our nation can spend thirty-five billion dollars a year to fight an unjust, evil war in Vietnam, and twenty billion dollars to put a man on the moon, it can spend billions of dollars to put God's children on their own two feet right here on earth."

So A and I hired this guy to come over and do problem solving on our computers.  Mine is an HP Pavilion from 1996 that has a 1.53gig hard drive.  Now I know that I need a new computer anyway, but I figured that while I sorting out what I should buy, it would be good to add another hard drive to this one so I can download email without spending more time going through this thing to figure out what I can delete to clear space every time.

Now the hard drive is installed and not really doing what it's supposed to do.  The bigger problem is that after he added this thing and moved stuff around to try to created some additional USABLE space on this computer (which hasn't really been accomplished), my Outlook Express seems to have an empty address book!!!

I've looked on the new D drive with no luck.  The guy said that he has a couple of ideas where it might be but it has been difficult to find a time for him to come back that works for everyone.  In the meantime, I don't have the damned address book and have been feeling quite panicked about the possibility that it might not be retrievable.  Especially since my email MAILING LISTS for PERFORMANCE ANNOUNCEMENTS are on it and I don't have them backed up anywhere!

There are a number of things I would like to post here, some updates on my life and one or two things I've seen that I'd want to paste in.  I'm feeling a little weird about doing so, however, because it's the first time I've gotten on to LJ in a couple of weeks and I haven't had a chance to read anyone else's entries for quite a while.  

Am I being silly or is there something to the idea that it it's unfair to ask other people to read my stuff when I haven't been able to take the time to read theirs recently?
I am horrified that our government has really started this war of aggression.
I don't remember whether I saw this on someone's lj or whether someone emailed this link to me but I was definitely amused.  http://www.ttr2.co.uk/wmd.htm
Damn - I missed the Grammys!  Does anyone have the show on tape or TIVO (DVD would be great too)?

After some resistance, I finally went ahead and registered for this Live Journal thing sometime last week.  I don't expect to post much, or even read most of what comes my way (especially if these last few days are a fair reflection of what kind of volume to expect).  None the less, here I am!  It sort of amazes me that minutes after I put a couple of folks on my friends list, I saw that they had put me on their own.  How do people know so fast?  (I know, they check their personal settings.)

I expect that it will take me a while to get a sense of all the ins and outs of LJ; I spent a little time checking out the FAQ and much more time (more time than I can really afford, really) navigating through the site and every time I go to the page of one of my friends, I find more friends and other people that I like out here that I imagine I will gradually add to my friends list.
